questions.text: What is the embryological origin of the structure marked in the X-ray?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the given X-ray image is the renal pelvis. It is embryologically derived from intermediate mesoderm.

The urinary and reproductive organs are developed from the intermediate mesoderm. 

After the notochord is formed, the intraembryonic mesoderm on either side can be seen organized into 3 layers:

  • Paraxial mesoderm: A thickened plate of the mesoderm close to the midline, on either side of the notochord. This forms the somitomeres and somites.
  • Intermediate mesoderm: Longitudinal strip of mesoderm that connects paraxial with the lateral plate mesoderm. The urinary and genital systems are derived from the intermediate mesoderm.
  • Lateral plate mesoderm: A thinner layer of mesoderm that lies laterally. This layer develops a large cavity called the intraembryonic coelom that gives rise to pericardial, pleural, and peritoneal cavities.

Related Pearl: Derivatives of Mesoderm

 

Mesoderm derivatives
Paraxial mesoderm
  • Skeletal muscles of the trunk, limbs, head, and neck
  • Extraocular muscles
  • Intrinsic muscles of the tongue
  • Bones: Vertebrae, ribs
  • Dermis of Skin
  • Duramater
Intermediate mesoderm
  • Urinary system: Kidneys, ureters, trigone of the urinary bladder
  • Dorsal part of prostatic urethra (males)
  • Gonads: Testes and ovaries
  • Genital ducts
  • Adrenal cortex
Lateral plate mesoderm
  • Bones: Sternum, limb bones
  • Serous membranes of body cavities: Pleura, pericardium, peritoneum
  • GIT layers: Lamina propria, muscularis mucosae, submucosa, muscularis externa, adventitia
  • Blood cells: Microglia, Kupffer cells
  • Cardiovascular system
  • Lymphatic system
  • Laryngeal cartilages

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is deficient in metachromatic leucodystrophy?
questions.solution:
Metachromatic leucodystrophy occurs due to the deficiency of arylsulfatase A enzyme.

Metachromatic leucodystrophy is an autosomal recessive disorder. Deficiency of arylsulfatase A enzyme leads to accumulation of sulfated glycosphingolipids in white matter with subsequent demyelination. Affected infants (infantile form) present with cognitive deterioration, muscle weakness, hypotonia, nystagmus, myoclonic seizures, optic atrophy and progressive paralysis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man sustained a closed, diaphyseal tibial fracture of the left leg in a road traffic accident. As he had no distal neurovascular deficits or any open wound, he was managed conservatively with a cast for 6 weeks. After this period, he noticed a significant reduction in the girth of his left calf compared to the right. What is the type of atrophy likely to be responsible for this?
questions.solution:
Disuse atrophy due to decreased workload is seen in this scenario. Disuse atrophy occurs in a limb that has been immobilized following a fracture.

Physiologic atrophy:

  • Loss of hormonal stimulation: Atrophy of the uterus after parturition; atrophy of the endometrium, vaginal epithelium, and breast after menopause.
  • During embryonic development: Certain structures, like the notochord and thyroglossal duct, undergo atrophy during fetal development.

Pathologic atrophy:

  • Disuse Atrophy (decreased workload): e.g., atrophy in a limb that has been immobilized following a fracture
  • Denervation atrophy (loss of nerve supply): e.g., skeletal muscle atrophy following nerve injury
  • Ischemic atrophy: e.g., senile atrophy of the brain and heart due to atherosclerosis
  • Inadequate nutrition: e.g., severe muscle wasting in marasmus
  • Pressure atrophy: e.g., atrophy of surrounding uninvolved tissues caused by an enlarging benign tumor 

Mechanisms of atrophy:

  • Decreased protein synthesis because of decreased metabolic activity
  • Increased destruction of proteins by the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the properties of MHC proteins?

choices.text: MHC Class III- Presents extracellular antigens
MHC Class II - Presents intracellular antigens
MHC Class II - Expressed on antigen presenting cells
MHC Class I - Does not present antigens

questions.solution:
MHC proteins:

  • MHC Class I- Presents intracellular antigens, expressed by all the nucleated cells
  • MHC Class II- Presents extracellular antigens, expressed by antigen presenting cells
  • MHC Class III- include some complement components and TNF-alpha and Lymphotoxin-alpha, do not function in antigen presentation.

questions.text: A 23-year-old pregnant woman presented with features suggestive of thyrotoxicosis. Which of the following is not a treatment option for her condition?
questions.solution:
Radioactive iodine therapy is contraindicated during pregnancy and lactation. Therefore, it is not a treatment option in this patient.

Thyrotoxicosis in pregnancy:

The drug of choice for the treatment of thyrotoxicosis during the first trimester of pregnancy is propylthiouracil (PTU).

Methimazole and its prodrug (carbimazole) are usually avoided in the first trimester due to teratogenic risk. However, methimazole is used for the remainder of the pregnancy due to the concern for PTU-associated liver failure. 

Subtotal thyroidectomy can be performed during the mid-trimester.

Radioactive iodine crosses the placenta and causes the destruction of the fetal thyroid. Therefore, it is contraindicated during pregnancy and lactation.

Treatment of thyrotoxicosis in pregnancy

Trimester Treatment for thyrotoxicosis
First trimester
  • Propylthiouracil
Second trimester
  • Methimazole
  • Subtotal thyroidectomy
Third trimester
  • Methimazole

Related Pearl: Drug of choice for hyperthyroidism/thyrotoxicosis in pregnancy

In the 1st trimester: Propylthiouracil

In the 2nd and 3rd trimester: Methimazole

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient is diagnosed to have bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. He struggles to hear and understand speech despite appropriately fit hearing aids. The ENT specialist decided that a cochlear implant would be the best treatment for this patient. What is the site in which the electrode is placed?
questions.solution:
The electrode of a cochlear implant is placed in the scala tympani.

A cochlear implant is an electronic device that replaces the organ of Corti i.e. when hair cells of the organ of Corti are severely damaged these implants bypass it and directly stimulate the auditory nerve. In cochlear implant surgery, the electrode array is placed within the scala tympani of the cochlea. Thus, an intact vestibulocochlear (CN VIII) nerve and the higher auditory pathway a prerequisites for cochlear implant surgery.

It is indicated in severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss and in those who cannot benefit from hearing aids.

Note:

The auditory brainstem implant is placed in the lateral recess of the 4th ventricle. 

Related Pearl: Cochlear implant

A cochlear implant replaces the organ of Corti i.e. when hair cells of the organ of Corti are severely damaged these implants bypass it and directly stimulate the auditory nerve.

Indication: Bilateral severe sensorineural hearing loss i.e. > 70 dB.

Components:

Preoperative investigation: Complete audiological evaluation and HRCT and MRI (to detect the structure of cochlea, cochlear nerve and CNS abnormalities).

Surgical approach: Two surgical techniques to approach the cochlea for implantation are the facial recess approach (via facial recess) and the pericanal technique (via EAC).

Postoperatively: Activation of the device after 3-4 weeks and evaluation is by HRCT (MRI is contraindicated).

Contraindications:

  • Absence of cochlea (Michel aplasia)
  • Deafness due to absent cochlear nerve, lesions of cochlear nerve or lesions of the central auditory pathway

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of glare and discomfort of the eyes. Findings seen on slit-lamp examination are given below. He suffers from lupus erythematosus, for which he is being treated with chloroquine. Which of the following findings would you expect to see on a fundoscopy?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the slit lamp findings of cornea verticillata point to toxicity caused due to chloroquine. The fundoscopy in this patient is most likely to reveal bull’s eye maculopathy.

Prolonged administration of chloroquine leads to bull’s eye maculopathy.  

The image below shows bull’s eye maculopathy:

 

Causes of Bull’s eye maculopathy: 

  • Chloroquine maculopathy
  • Advanced Stargardt disease
  • Cone and cone-rod dystrophy
  • Fenestrated sheen macular dystrophy
  • Benign concentric annular macular dystrophy
  • Clofazimine retinopathy.

Cornea Verticillata is a condition where a whorl-like opacity is seen in the corneal epithelium seen on treatment with medica­tion such as chloroquine, amiodarone, phenothiazines, and indomethacin. It is also seen in Fabry disease.

Hypotonic maculopathy is the maculopathy occurring because of decreased intraocular pressure (less than 6 mmHg). It usually occurs due to excessive drainage after glaucoma filtration surgery.

questions.text: A study to determine the association between maternal smoking during pregnancy and low birth weight is being carried out. It involves obtaining smoking histories from pregnant women during their antenatal visits and then subsequently assessing the birth weight of their babies soon after delivery. What type of study is this?
questions.solution:
The study of choice is a prospective cohort study. This study is a prospective cohort study because the subjects (pregnant women) were categorized on the basis of exposure or lack of exposure to a risk factor -smoking during pregnancy. They were followed to determine if the outcome, the low birth weight of the babies occurred or not.
 
A prospective cohort study is a study in which the outcome has not yet occurred at the time that the investigations begin. They begin in the present and continue into the future. The design of a prospective cohort is shown below.
A retrospective cohort study is when both the exposure and outcome have occurred before the investigations and study is undertaken. An example would be if the charts in a hospital from the previous year were reviewed, and mothers were classified as smokers or nonsmokers based on records. The records are then followed through time and then the birth weight of the children in both groups are compared. It is also called a historical cohort study, a prospective study in retrospect, or a non-concurrent prospective study.
 
In a case-control study of the same, low birth weight infants would be selected as the cases and normal birth weight babies as the controls. The frequency of maternal smoking would then be compared in the two groups.
 
In cross-sectional studies, exposure and outcome are measured at the same point in time.

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient presents to the OPD with complaints of swelling in front of the neck as shown in the image. On examination, it is a well-defined smooth midline swelling that moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue. The swelling was surgically removed and histopathological examination of the specimen showed the presence of malignant cells. Which of the following is the most common variant of carcinoma likely to be seen in such cases?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the image given are suggestive of the thyroglossal cyst and papillary carcinoma is the most common type of cancer (seen in 85% cases) found in thyroglossal cysts.

The thyroid gland descends early in fetal life from the base of the tongue towards its position in the lower neck. At the time of descent, the hyoid bone has not been formed and the track of the thyroid gland is variable, passing in front, through, or behind the eventual position of the hyoid body. Thyroglossal cyst represents the persistence of the track of the thyroid gland and can be found adjacent to the midline.

Classically the cyst moves upwards on swallowing and on tongue protrusion, and it indicates attachment to the hyoid bone. Although they often occur in children they may also present in adults, even as late as the 6th or 7th decade.

Complications:

  • The most common complication is infection.
  • 1% of thyroglossal duct cysts are found to be malignant of which the most common type of cancer is papillary (85%). Medullary thyroid carcinomas are not found in thyroglossal duct cysts

Treatment:

Sistrunk’s operation

Excision of the cyst along and the whole thyroglossal tract up to the foramen caecum along with the removal of the body of the hyoid bone. This is essential to avoid recurrence of the sinuses.

Note:

Sistrunk operation with total thyroidectomy is indicated only if a papillary carcinoma is found to arise from the cyst in the setting of : 

  • Lymph node metastasis
  • Thyroid nodularity
  • Cyst wall invasion
  • Large tumors

The image below shows the Sistrunk procedure-

Related Pearl: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma. It is most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 

The mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade and is more common in women than men (2:1). Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion.

It usually presents as a cold nodule on the scan. Histological findings include:

  • Branching papillae 
  • Follicles with the fibrovascular stalk
  • Psammoma bodies
  • Nuclear changes- 
    • Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei
    • Pseudo-inclusions
    • Nuclear grooves.

Lymph node metastasis is common. Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma. The most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain.

It has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

Related Pearl: Thyroid Malignancy - Most Commons

  • Most common primary thyroid malignancy – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with radiation - Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common malignancy of thyroid associated with lymphatic spread – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with blood and bone metastasis – Follicular carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy in iodine sufficient areas – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy in iodine deficient areas – Follicular carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with Multi Nodular Goiter - Follicular carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy associated with amyloid - Medullary carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy associated with MEN 2 syndrome - Medullary carcinoma
  • Most aggressive thyroid malignancy with worst prognosis - Anaplastic carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy with best prognosis - Papillary carcinoma

questions.text: A lady with 2 weeks of amenorrhea and a positive urine pregnancy test came for medical termination of the pregnancy. Menstrual aspiration is being performed. Which is the instrument used for this procedure?
questions.solution:
Karman’s cannula (image 3) is used for menstrual aspiration.

Menstrual regulation or aspiration is the aspiration of the endometrial cavity 1-3 weeks after a missed period in a woman with a previous normal cycle and a positive urine pregnancy test. It is performed using Karman's cannula.

Procedure -

  • Under aseptic precautions, the cervix may be gently dilated using 4-5 mm size dilators.
  • Then 5-6mm Karman’s cannula is inserted and attached to a 50ml syringe for suction.
  • The cannula is rotated, pushed in and out with gentle strokes.

This procedure is contraindicated in advanced pregnancy and in the presence of local pelvic inflammation.

The drawback of the procedure - an implanted zygote can be missed, an ectopic pregnancy can be unrecognized.

Other options:

  • Instrument 1 is Rubins cannula. It is used for hysterosalpingography.
  • Instrument 2 is Leech Wilkinson's cannula. It can be identified by the spiral cone at the tip and is used for hysterosalpingography.
  • Instrument 4 is Simpson's uterine sound. It can be identified by the markings used for measurement and is used to measure the length of the uterus.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text:
A 26-year-old woman presents with acute onset abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. She has a low-grade fever, with a pulse rate of 90 bpm and blood pressure of 126/84 mm Hg. She has regular menstrual cycles of 28 days. Pelvic examination shows a tender right adnexal mass. Ultrasound scan reveals a swollen oedematous ovary, globular in shape with disruption in adnexal flow seen on doppler. What is the most probable diagnosis?

Urine pregnancy testing- negative
Serum β-HCG level- 1 mIU/L
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of ovarian torsion.

Torsion of the ovaries is a gynecological emergency and is most commonly seen in women of the reproductive age group. Ovarian cysts including mucous cystadenomas and dermoid cysts have the highest risks of undergoing torsion. Adnexal masses measuring >6 cm in diameter have the highest rates of torsion.

A patient with torsion presents with sharp lower abdominal pain, usually localized to the involved side with radiation to the flank, groin, or thigh. Nausea and vomiting are commonly associated. Adnexal necrosis may cause a low-grade fever. 

During torsion, the low-pressure veins are initially compressed by the twisting pedicle. This leads to continuous inflow with decreased outflow causing stromal edema and congestion. The increasing stromal swelling later compresses the arteries causing ischemia and necrosis.

On USG, the ovary appears enlarged, globular, and has a heterogenous appearance compared to the contralateral ovary due to edema, engorgement, and hemorrhage. Twisting of the vascular pedicle may give rise to a 'whirlpool sign', a round hyperechoic structure with concentric hypoechoic stripes. Colour Doppler sonography should be performed in suspected torsion as it may show disruption to blood flow, which is highly suggestive of torsion. However, some cases of incomplete torsion or chronic torsion, may not show decreased flow on Doppler. MRI or CT imaging can be used in patients with normal Doppler but with characteristic signs and symptoms of torsion, to confirm or rule out the diagnosis.

Management involves urgent laparotomy or laparoscopic evaluation. Salvage of the involved adnexa with the removal of any associated cyst/tumor and possible oophoropexy are the goals. However, necrosis of the adnexa necessitates the removal of the adnexal structures.

Other options:

Option A: In a woman of reproductive age group, ovulatory pain following the rupture of Graafian follicle (ovulation) may present similarly with lower abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. This patient has a regular 28-day cycle and should have ovulated around the 14th day. 

Option B: Tubo-ovarian abscess presents with a more indolent course, and may be associated with fever. The characteristic appearance on USG is of a complex, multilocular mass. 

Option C: Ectopic pregnancy presents with nausea, vomiting, and adnexal pain, with or without a mass. However, this patient has a negative UPT, and serum β-HCG level is in the non-pregnant range (< 2 mIU/L) excluding ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male patient presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of severe joint pain on his big toe with multiple such episodes in the past. The X-ray shows the 'G' sign. Which of the following signs is also expected to be seen on ultrasound in this condition?
questions.solution:
The X-ray of this patient shows Martel's sign/ G-sign which refers to the punched-out lytic lesion and overhanging margin of the new bone. It is seen in chronic gout. Among the given options, the radiological sign that is seen in chronic gout is the double contour sign. 

Double contour sign is an ultrasound finding that is characterized by an echogenic line on the outer surface of the joint cartilage due to the deposition of monosodium urate crystals on the surface of articular cartilage.

Gout is a metabolic disease that is characterized by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in joints and connective tissue. It is more common in males and it usually presents as monoarthritis that may be acute and episodic or chronic. 

  • Acute gout presents with a joint that is red, hot, swollen, and extremely tender on examination. The metatarsophalangeal joint of the great toe is the most frequently involved joint.

Chronic gout may present with chronic nonsymmetric synovitis, gouty arthritis, and periarticular tophaceous deposits.

Synovial fluid analysis of joint aspirate is diagnostic and shows the following features-

  • Increased leukocyte count with a neutrophilic predominance
  • Negatively birefringent crystals on polarized light microscopy of the synovial fluid.

Other options-

Option A: Linguine sign is seen in intracapsular rupture of silicone breast implant.

Option C: The Accordion sign is seen in pseudomembranous colitis.

Option D: Water lily sign is seen in hydatid cyst.

 

Ultrasound double contour sign:

 

Negatively birefringent monosodium urate crystals-

questions.text: Following general anaesthesia for a procedure, a 45-year-old lady experienced prolonged somnolescence. On administration of physostigmine, she showed rapid improvement of her mental status. Which of the following drugs is not likely to cause this syndrome?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of the central anticholinergic syndrome, which is not caused by glycopyrrolate. 

Glycopyrrolate usually does not produce central anticholinergic syndrome because is a quaternary amine compound, lipid insoluble, and does not cross the blood-brain barrier. Glycopyrrolate blocks the peripheral muscarinic side effects (caused by increased acetylcholine levels by neostigmine) without causing unwanted central anticholinergic effects.

Drugs that can cause anticholinergic syndrome include:

  • Atropine
  • Scopolamine
  • First-generation antihistamines 
  • Tricyclic antidepressants 
  • Phenothiazines

The anticholinergic syndrome can present with central manifestations ranging from delirium and agitation to CNS depression, stupor and coma. It is a rare reaction due to either overdose or any unusual reaction to the usage of the drugs mentioned above. Physostigmine is useful in reversing the central anticholinergic syndrome produced by overdosage or an unusual reaction to these drugs.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male patient is brought to the psychiatry OPD by his wife. He is convinced that the lead actress of a film he watched recently is deeply in love with him and wants to marry him. She also says that he is socially withdrawn and doesn't have many friends. Upon conducting a mental status examination, there are no other significant findings. What is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the man has a false belief that his chairman wants to marry him, which is a delusion of love, also known as de Clérambault syndrome/erotomania /psychose passionelle.

Delusions are false beliefs that are firmly held despite objective and obvious contradictory proof. It can be present in conditions like schizophrenia, mania, major depressive disorders, and delusional disorders. 

The erotomania is more common in women but can be seen in men as well. The patient feels that someone, who is usually of a higher status, is deeply in love with them. Patients with this delusion are usually solitary, withdrawn, dependent, and sexually inhibited. It is usually sudden in onset and runs a chronic course. It is seen in conditions like schizophrenia, mood disorder, and other organic disorders.

Other options: 

Option B: Capgras syndrome is a delusion of misidentification. Here, the patient believes that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double, i.e. an impostor.

Option C: In the delusion of reference, the patient believes that events, objects, or behaviour of others have a special significance to him. For, when he comes across people talking, he might assume that the discussion is about them.

Option D: Othello syndrome is the presence of marked morbid, pathological, or delusional jealousy. The patient here has doubts of infidelity, which is also known as conjugal paranoia. The person holds an abnormal belief that their spouse or partner is being unfaithful. 

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

Related Pearl: Disorders of thought and perception

DISORDERS OF THOUGHT

DISORDER OF STREAM OF THOUGHT

(A) Disorder of tempo

(i) Flight of Ideas

Continuous flow of rapid speech that jumps from topic to topic

  • "I like mangoes, the weather is nice, India is great"

(ii) Retardation of thinking

Slow speed of speech and a prolonged latent period before a response

  • "I went to the market (pause)......... the shop was closed"

(iii) Circumstantialities

Inclusion of irrelevant details and going on in a roundabout manner, but their thought ultimately reaches the answer

  • Doctor: "How did you get that bruise?"

  • Patient: "I woke up and had a cup of coffee, read the newspaper and went for a walk. It was a wonderful day in the park. I returned home and watched the TV. I took a nap in the afternoon after lunch. I slipped and fell in the bathroom. The fall gave me this bruise."

(iv) Clang associations

Jumping from one word to another irrelevant rhyming word

  • I am Sam...I like jam...I travel in a tram"

(B) Disorder of continuity

(i) Perseveration

Repetition of out of context words, phrases, or ideas beyond the point of relevance.

  • Q1. What's your name?: "Rahul"

  • Q2. Where are you from?: "Rahul"

  • Q3. How old are you?: "Rahul"

(ii) Thought blocking

A sudden disruption of thought or a break in the flow of ideas

  • "I went to the market (extreme silence)...................."

DISORDER OF FORM OF THOUGHT

(i) Tangentiality

In response to a question, the patient gives a reply that is appropriate to the general topic but does not answer the question exactly. The speech moves away from the actual answer.

  • Doctor: "Have you had any trouble sleeping lately?"
  • Patient: "I usually sleep in my bed, but now I'm sleeping on the sofa"

(ii) Derailment

A breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal-directedness. The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense.

  • "Some people just don't understand why I had breakfast in America during the first world war"

(iii) Neologisms

Bringing in new words that do not exist.

  • The world is not 'gooder' for people like me"

(iv) Desultory thoughts

Speech is grammatically correct, however, sudden unrelated ideas force their way in from time to time.

  • My actual problem is that the people never understand me and my stomach feels like an empty bucket"

(v) Word salad

Using a mixture of unintelligible meaningless words and sentences

  • Tree bus rain food home car tiger"

DISORDER OF POSSESSION OF THOUGHT
A. Thought alienation

(i) Thought insertion

Thoughts are being inserted into the patient's mind and they recognize them as being foreign and coming from without any stimulus

  • "I have repeated thoughts of killing my neighbors and I believe aliens are putting these ideas into my head at night"

(ii) Thought withdrawal

Delusion that someone or something is removing from one's mind and the patient has no power over this.

  • "Lately, I am losing all my memories and I believe that the 'government agents' are stealing them when I go to sleep"

(iii) Thought broadcasting

Belief that one's thoughts are quietly escaping from one's mind and that other people might be able to access them and hear or see them.

  • "I believe my exact thoughts appear on the TV and the internet and I think I can broadcast them globally" 

(iv) Thought echo

Patient hears the 'echo' of his own thoughts in the form of a voice after he has made the thought.

  • "I thought of making a sandwich in the morning and surprisingly a voice, from nowhere, told me to make a sandwich out loud" 

 B. Obsessions and Compulsions

1. Obsessions

Recurrent and persistent thoughts, impulses. or images that cause distress to oneself.

  • Fear of dirt or contamination
  • Fear of becoming ill
  • Constant thoughts of a certain number
  • Need for symmetry or exactness
  • Worry about whether something has been done "right"
  • Forbidden sexual or religious thoughts

2. Compulsions

Repetitive behaviors or actions that the person feels driven to perform in response to an obsession

  • Washing hands
  • Blinking eyes
  • Counting items, such as currency
  • Checking to see if doors are locked
  • Arranging items in a certain way
  • Requiring constant approval from people around them

 
 DISORDER OF CONTENT OF THOUGHT

(i) Phobias

Persistent fear of an object or situation, typically disproportional to the actual danger posed, in which the sufferer goes to great lengths in avoiding it

  • Arachnophobia - fear of spider
  • Barophobia - fear of gravity
  • Cynophobia - fear of dogs
  • Hemophobia - fear of blood
  • Nosocomephobia - fear of hospitals

(ii) Religious preoccupations

Thoughts involving religious themes or subject matter.

  • "I get instructions from God on how to make my country great"

(iii) Ideas of hopelessness

Thoughts of complete despair where the patient strongly believes that the circumstances will never get better for him.

  • "I am never going to pass my final exams, no matter how hard I study"

(iv) Antisocial urges

Thoughts of indulging in some behaviors or actions that harm or lack consideration for the well being of others.

  • "I have these urges to go rob a bank or blackmail my neighbors for their money"

(v) Delusions

False beliefs that are strongly held and unchangeable in the face of refuting evidence and that are not consistent with the person's educational, social and cultural background.

The three main criteria for a belief to be considered a delusion are:

  • Certainty (held with complete confidence)
  • Incorrigibility (not changeable by proof to the contrary)
  • Impossibility or falsity of content (implausible, bizarre or patently untrue)
 DISORDERS OF PERCEPTIONS

  • Illusion: Misinterpretation of real external stimuli.

  • Hallucination: False sensory perception, externally.

  • Pseudohallucination: False sensory perception from within and having an insight.

  • Depersonalization: Feeling as if one is disconnected from reality, feeling detached from one's own thoughts and one's own physical body.

    "I sometimes drift into a dream-like state where I lose contact with my own self"

  • Derealization: Alteration in the perception or experience of the external world so that it seems unreal.

    "The world and everything around is nothing but just a dream"

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presented with complaints of a rash in the elbows and knees as shown below. It has been associated with intense itching for a few weeks. On further evaluation, direct immunofluorescence  shows IgA deposition in the dermal papillae and serology revealed the presence of anti-TTG.  Which of the following drugs will you prescribe as first line for this patient along with dietary modification?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a middle-aged male patient with positive anti-TTG, multiple pruritic erythematous macules and papules on the knees and elbows (as shown in image) and IgA deposition in dermal papillae are suggestive of dermatitis herpetiformis in association with gluten-sensitive enteropathy. Dapsone will be the first-line drug in this case.

Dapsone helps in short-term management of dermatitis herpetiformis by its effects on neutrophil function and recruitment.

Adverse side effects:

  • Hemolysis especially in patients with G6PD deficiency
  • Methaemoglobinaemia
  • Agranulocytosis
  • Dapsone hypersensitivity syndrome
  • Peripheral neuropathy

Dapsone should always be used in combination with a gluten‐free diet. It doesn't show any effect on the gastrointestinal symptoms of the associated gluten-sensitive enteropathy.

Dermatitis herpetiformis is a chronic, intensely pruritic, skin condition associated with gluten‐sensitive enteropathy. 

  • It can also be associated with autoimmune thyroid disease.
  • It is associated with HLA‐DQ2.
  • It typically appears in the 4th decade, and the patients present with itching and rash, most typically over the extensor surfaces of the elbows, knees, buttocks, and scalp.
  • They may also have symptoms associated with gluten-sensitive enteropathies, like bloating, diarrhea and other gastrointestinal complaints.

On examination, multiple erythematous macules and papules can be seen over the extensor aspects. They appear symmetrical and heal without scarring. The oral cavity may show mucosal abnormalities and enamel pits.

Diagnosis can be made by clinical features, histopathology, direct immunofluorescence testing, and serology.

The histopathology of an intact vesicle in dermatitis herpetiformis will show subepidermal blister formation with neutrophils located at the tips of the dermal papillae. Perivascular infiltrates can also be seen.

Direct immunofluorescence can be done to the skin samples taken from the lesion and perilesional skin. It will show the deposition of IgA antibodies in the papillary dermis in a granular or fibrillar pattern. Complement 3 may also be found along with the IgA deposits.

Serology many show the presence of IgA anti-endomysial autoantibodies that target epidermal transglutaminase 3.

Treatment ladder for Dermatitis herpetiformis:

First-line:

  • Gluten-free diet is the mainstay of treatment
  • Dapsone - short term management of the symptoms
  • Potent topical steroid

Second-line:

  • Sulphamethoxypyridazine

Third-line:

  • Sulphasalazine 
  • Sulphapyridine  

The below image shows the deposition of IgA antibodies in the papillary dermis in a granular pattern. These antibodies are epidermal transglutaminase 3.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male patient presents to the OPD for evaluation of low backache. The patient gives a history that he also feels pain in the back of the leg and at the ankles. On examination there is decreased sensation in the ankle region and ankle jerk reflex is diminished. The test shown in the image is positive. Which of the following is not an absolute indication for surgical management in this patient?

choices.text: Marked progressive weakness of the muscles

questions.solution:
The clinical features and a positive straight leg raising test as shown in the image are suggestive of an intervertebral disc prolapse involving L5-S1 nerve root. Recurrent episodes of severe sciatica is only a relative indication for surgical management.

Indications for surgical management: 

Absolute indications:

  • Failed conservative management.
  • Marked progressive weakness of muscles.
  • Progressive neurological deficit.
  • Cauda equina paralysis.

Relative Indications:

  • Recurrent episodes of incapacitating sciatica
  • Pain unrelieved by complete rest from activity.

Intervertebral disc prolapse

Features of IVDP pain:

  • Pain is increased by flexion episodes, sneezing, coughing, straining, and sitting. 
  • Pain is decreased by rest and in the semi-Fowler position. Semi-Fowler position is lying in a bed supine with the head of the bed raised at approximately 30 to 45 degrees.
  • Leg pain equal to or more than the back pain in IVDP cases is evidence of involvement of the nerve root due to the herniated disc.

Important tests for diagnosis:

1. Straight Leg Raising Test (SLRT) or Lasegue sign

This is done to assess nerve root irritation in the lumbosacral area.  The patient is made to lie on the back with the head extended, with hips and legs in the neutral position. The affected leg is then passively and slowly raised by the ankle with the knee fully extended. The examiner stops further leg elevation when pain is elicited. Normally it should be possible to raise the limb to 80–90 degrees. The SLRT test is positive if the patient develops pain when the leg is between 30 and 60/70 degrees from horizontal. The pain should be radicular type and radiating to the back of the thigh or to the calf.

 

2. Bragard test (or Sciatic stretch test or Flip test)

Perform SLRT. At the point where the patient experiences discomfort, the leg is lowered a little. The stretching and pain become less. At this angle, the ankle is passively dorsiflexed. If the pain at the back of the thigh or in the calf is felt again, the test is positive. This is also called reinforcement positive or Bragard’s sign positive

 

3. Crossed SLRT (or well-leg raising test or Fajersztajn sign)

When SLRT is performed on the unaffected side, the patient may feel pain on the affected side. This is termed a contralateral positive SLRT or crossed SLRT positive. It is a very specific sign of root compression. It becomes positive usually when there is severe compression due to a centrally located prolapse.

4. Bowstring sign (or popliteal compression test)

The ‘bowstring sign’ is even more specific for disc prolapse than SLRT. Perform SLRT until the patient experiences sciatic pain. Without reducing the amount of lift, bend the knee so as to relax the sciatic nerve (Buckling sign). Buttock pain is immediately relieved. The examiner then presses the popliteal fossa to stretch the lateral popliteal nerve behind the lateral tibial condyle. This will tighten the nerve like a bowstring and re-induce the pain.

 

5. Femoral stretch (reverse Lasegue test or Mackiewicz sign)

The patient lies prone. The examiner flexes the knee to the thigh and the hip is passively extended. The test is positive if the patient experiences anterior thigh pain. This test is usually positive for L2-L3 and L3-L4 (high lumbar) protrusions

 

Treatment:

Conservative:

  • Continuous bed rest and traction for 2 weeks will reduce the herniation in over 90% of cases.
  • Back exercises and posture correction are also a part of conservative management
  • Epidural steroids

Surgical: Surgical procedures include laminectomy, hemilaminectomy, fenestration surgery, and microscopic & endoscopic lumbar discectomy.

questions.text: A woman brought her 13-month-old daughter to the pediatric OPD with recurrent urinary tract infections. Investigations reveal Grade-III vesicoureteral reflux and acute UTI. After treating her infection, which of the following investigation will she be followed up with, after 6 months?
questions.solution:
A dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) scan may be done after 4–6 months of acute infection as it may help to locate and delineate the scarring.

Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) severity is graded according to the appearance of the urinary tract on a contrast voiding cystourethrogram.

It is classified into 5 grades (Grade I to V):

Grading of vesicoureteral reﬂux:

  • Grade I: VUR into a non-dilated ureter
  • Grade II: VUR into the upper collecting system without dilation
  • Grade III: VUR into the dilated ureter and/or blunting of calyceal fornices.
  • Grade IV: VUR into a grossly dilated ureter
  • Grade V: Massive VUR, with significant ureteral dilation and tortuosity and loss of the papillary impression.

In a typical first episode of urinary tract infection (UTI) in children, initial imaging should be ultrasonography of the kidneys, ureters, and bladder.

A Voiding cystourethrogram is indicated only if the ultrasound study is abnormal, the patient has atypical features, or after a recurrent febrile UTI.

A dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) scan may be done after 4–6 months of acute infection as it may help to locate and delineate the scarring.

Magnetic resonance imaging does not have any significant role in the follow-up of this condition.

questions.text: A young woman was admitted for ingestion of several acetaminophen tablets. After 2 weeks of admission, she developed disturbed sleep and mild confusion. Investigations revealed deranged prothrombin time and bleeding time. The resident wanted to assess the requirement of liver transplantation using the King's College Hospital criteria. All of the following parameters are required to evaluate this patient except?
questions.solution:
King's college hospital criteria for paracetamol overdose does not include age < 10 or > 40 years. This parameter is included in the non paracetamol cases of liver failure.

King's college hospital criteria is a selection criterion in acute liver failure for liver transplantation. It includes the following parameters:

Liver transplantation is indicated in acetaminophen-induced ALF if there is a presence of

  • Either pH <7.3
  • Or all of the following
    • Prothrombin time >100 sec
    • Serum creatinine level >3.4 mg/dL (300 μmol/L)
    • Grade 3-4 encephalopathy

Liver transplantation is indicated in nonacetaminophen causes of ALF if there is a presence of 

  • Either prothrombin time >100 sec
  • Or any three of the following
    • Jaundice to encephalopathy time > 7 days
    • Age < 10 or > 40 years
    • Indeterminate or drug-induced causes
    • Bilirubin > 300 μmol/L (>3.4 mg/dL)
    • Prothrombin time > 50 secs
  • Or Factor V level < 15% and encephalopathy grade 3 or 4

Related Pearl: Revised Model for End-stage liver disease (MELD) scoring system: MELD 3.0

MELD 3.0 score has the following components (Mnemonic F BASIC)

  • Female sex
  • Bilirubin
  • Albumin
  • Serum sodium (mEq/L)
  • INR (International Normalized ratio)
  • Creatinine

Uses:

  • Predict short-term prognosis in patients undergoing transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) insertion
  • Assess and prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation
  • Assess prognosis in cirrhosis

questions.text: The rate of postmortem cooling is higher in which among the following situations?

choices.text: An adult body kept in a dry environment
A body with excess fat kept in a closed room
A fully clothed body kept under a blanket
A body kept in a well ventilated humid environment

questions.solution:
The rate of post mortem cooling is higher in a body kept in a well ventilated humid environment. 

Moist air is a better conductor of heat than dry air, therefore postmortem cooling is more rapid in a humid environment than dry environment. A body kept in a well ventillated room will cool more rapidly than one kept in a closed room.

Rate of cooling is slow when the body is clothed as clothes are bad conductors of heat. 

Fat is a bad conductor of heat. Fat bodies cool slowly and lean bodies cool rapidly.

Factors increasing the rate of postmortem cooling:

  • Increased difference in the temperature between body and the atmosphere
  • Large body surface area
  • Children and old aged people
  • Higher humidity and rapid air velocity
  • Body immersed in running water

Rate of cooling is decreased in:

  • Excess fat
  • Edema
  • Body covered with clothing
  • Bodies in small, ill-ventilated room
